Notes: No new policy. Schools are teaching in-person with certain precautions. Ex. teachers wearing masks, students wearing masks.  On 13 January 2022, National Cabinet agreed to a national framework to promote a nationally consistent approach to the ongoing delivery of high-quality education for all students during COVID-19. This framework ensure all schools are open and be able to stay open, with as little disruption from COVID-19 as possible.    https://archive.ph/alD9N  https://archive.ph/aW6iv

As of 31 March the majority of the Level 2 health measure in place were rolled back to Level 1 (Western Australia region). More widely, proof of vaccination requirements remain in place for certain businesses and venues (ex. hospitality) nationally.     Western Australia Level 1 measures are that:  Density and capacity limits  The 2 square metre (2sqm) rule and 500 patron capacity limit applies to:  -Licensed hospitality venues  -Nightclubs    Convention centres and function centres  The 2sqm rule also applies to:  -Fitness venues  -Entertainment venues  -Galleries and museums  -Places of worship  -Hairdressers, beauty services, spas, saunas, tattoo and massage parlours  -Perth Crown Complex  -Community, recreation or youth centre facilities.    Masks are required for people aged 8 years and over (year 3 and over for schools):  - everywhere indoors, other than in the home  - when on public transport, in taxis and rideshare vehicles  - at hospitals and residential aged care or residential disability care facilities.    https://archive.ph/kUJ4m

Starting 29 April Western Australia dropped from Level 1 to "Baseline public health and social measures". However Tasmania still has some capacity limits on businesses:   - Hospitality venues such as restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, pubs, clubs, bars, RSLs and community clubs can accept up to 250 people per undivided indoor space and up to 500 people per undivided outdoor area at any one time.  - The density limit at these premises is 1 person per 2 square metres.  - Patrons at restaurants, cafÃ©s, pubs and clubs must provide contact details and the time of entry of at least one member of their group for possible contact-tracing purposes.    https://archive.ph/W2zd9  https://archive.ph/Xa21M

Starting 14 April the indoor gathering restrictions in Western Australia have been lifted (previously limited to 10 people). Most locations have no restrictions with the exception of Tasmania which has a limit of 100 people in place since 2021.    Gatherings at residential premises â including shacks â are limited to 100 people (including children and babies) at any one time. This limit includes all residents of the household and the people who ordinarily reside at the house or shack.    The household gathering limit of 100 people applies whether the gathering is indoors or outdoors, and for all types of gatherings, including barbecues and celebrations.    https://archive.ph/ZjA9r  https://archive.ph/Rwegp

As of 31 March in the Western Australia region "Level 1" measures are in effect which has eased travel but enforces restrictions against travel to Aboriginal communities. To help keep remote Aboriginal communities safe from COVID-19, there are strict travel restrictions in place. Tourists and travellers are not allowed to enter. Vaccination status does not affect this restriction.     Under the WA Governmentâs Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  - providing essential services and supplies  - going to work or school there  - entering for family or cultural reasons  - delivering a community program or activity  - entering in an emergency.  These people cannot enter a community if they have COVID-19 or symptoms of COVID-19, or if they are waiting for a test result or have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.  - Travellers can drive through a remote Aboriginal community only if they do not stop or come into contact with any person in the community.  - Police have the power to enforce the travel restrictions, and fines of up to $50,000 can be issued.    Other AUS regional restrictions vary but are more lenient.     https://archive.ph/8tKNt

Starting 17 April restrictions will be relaxed where travelers no longer must provide a negative pre-departure test to enter Australia.    International travellers into and out of Australia will still be required to provide proof of double vaccination against COVID-19.    The following additional measures have ended:  - restrictions on the entry of cruise vessels into and within Australian territory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220425173740/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/australias-biosecurity-emergency-pandemic-measures-to-end  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425174009/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Starting 29 April Western Australia dropped from Level 1 to "Baseline public health and social measures". However Tasmania still has mask requirements.   Anyone aged 12 years and over must wear a face mask in the following indoor areas once they leave their own or someone elseâs home â unless theyâre exempt:  - hospitals (excluding patients)  - residential aged care facilities (excluding residents) and in-home and community aged care  - residential disability care facilities (excluding residents) and in-home care, including disability support provider and NDIS-funded services  - correctional facilities (excluding prisoners and detainees)  - health care and medical facilities and services/treatments, including allied health  - primary (teachers, staff and visitors only) and secondary schools (including students)  - early childhood services, including childcare  - public transport, including buses, passenger ferries, taxis and rideshare services  - airports and aircraft  - the Spirit of Tasmania and ports  You donât need to wear a face mask outdoors. However, you may choose to wear one as an extra safety measure.  https://archive.ph/W2zd9  https://archive.ph/xVoyd

As of 31 March in the Western Australia region "Level 1" measures are now in effect. Part of these restrictions include external visitor restrictions for residential aged and disability care facilities:  - 2 visitors permitted per resident patient per day  - Masks must be worn by staff and visitors indoors and outdoors  - Proof of vaccination applies for visitors    National policy still in place outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://archive.ph/kUJ4m  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

Starting 29 April Western Australia dropped from Level 1 to "Baseline public health and social measures". However part of these restrictions include external visitor restrictions for residential aged and disability care facilities (same as previous threat levels):  - 2 visitors permitted per resident patient per day  - Masks must be worn by staff and visitors indoors and outdoors  - Proof of vaccination applies for visitors    National policy still in place outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://archive.ph/W2zd9  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

Brunei has returned to in-person teaching for most levels (except primary schools), after schools were moved online after the surge in Covid-19 cases due to the Omicron wave.    As reported by the Scoop,    'Child care centres, kindergartens, secondary schools, religious schools, colleges and sixth form centres will resume classroom learning on either April 4 or 5, pending the sighting of the moon this Friday which will determine the first day of Ramadan.    However only primary schools with less than 50 pupils â such as those in rural areas â will be allowed to reopen, while the rest must wait until the government kicks off its COVID-19 vaccination programme for children aged 5-11.    Face-to-face learning has been suspended since March 7 after schools reported low attendance at the height of the Omicron surge.    Before retuning to classrooms, the minister urged parents to conduct ART testing on their children twice a week and to regularly report their results to the school.    âIf there are any students experiencing symptoms such as a cold or cough, we hope parents or guardians can send them to the clinic for treatment and not send them to school.â    He added that adolescents aged 12 to 17 who are not yet vaccinated will be allowed to return to schools next week, rescinding a previous policy which did not allow unvaccinated children to attend in-person classes.    This recent announcement brings to an end the third school closure since the pandemic started. The first suspension of classroom learning lasted from March 26, 2020 to June 2, 2020, while the second closure spanned August 9, 2021 to January 2, 2022.'    See the Scoop's report, entitled "Schools to resume face-to-face learning next week", archived at https://archive.ph/ElXxD

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 15 April.    Business premises can operate to 75 percent or 300-people capacity, whichever is smaller, from 15 December.    "From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)    Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)   Government offices and service counters. "    Additionally, the civil service will return to normal in-person working and standard working hours.  "In the early endemic phase, civil servants will fully return to the office and normal working hours will be reinstated from 7.45am to 12.15pm and from 1.30pm to 4.30pm."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1561.0-1627.41

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 15 April.    "Public venues can increase capacity to 75%  As Brunei moves into the early endemic phase, the government also announced further easing of restrictions that will come into effect on December 15, 2021 and last until January 14, 2022.   During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place.   From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)  Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)  Government offices and service counters.     Members of the public are permitted to host large gatherings such as weddings, but attendance is limited to 75 percent of the venue capacity or not more than 300 people  â whichever is the smaller number. Buffet services are still not allowed, except for dome serving, and distribution of packaged meals is encouraged instead."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 15 April.    With the transition to the early endemic phase, the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications have advised that transport vehicles are now limited to 75% capacity, up from 50% previously.    "2. Similarly with Public Transport such as buses, taxis and e-hailing services as well as transport of mining boats, passenger boats and passenger ships where the number of passengers is increased to 75% of the previous total passenger capacity of 50% (excluding drivers) and ensure the existence of social incarceration measures. This means that the vehicle seat capacity and number of passengers for taxis and e-Hailing vehicles such as DART service is according to the vehicle seat capacity for example the vehicle seat capacity is 5 people and the passenger limit is 3 people and so on if the capacity is 7 people and the passenger limit is 4 people."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived in Malay, at https://archive.vn/vfs6b (see point 2 under SOP Pembukaan Sekolah Memandu dan Pengangkutan Awam)

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 15 April.    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work.    The night-time curfews are no longer in force. No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below). Although a green travel list comprising other countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia was originally envisioned for the lifting on restriction on non-essential inbound travel on Jan 1, 2022, this has now been scrapped due to concerns over the Omicron variant.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the [US Embassy in Brunei's website](https://archive.ph/WNIKw), archived at https://archive.ph/WNIKw  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Brunei backtracks on plans to lift travel curbs over Omicron concerns", archived at https://archive.vn/8lobr

As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 08 Apr, foreigners are now allowed. As cross-border travel via land and sea is still suspended, the only way to enter Brunei now is via air.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    -   Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?Â  No.      -   Starting April 1, 2022, Brunei citizens and residents who have completed three doses of the COVID-19 vaccination, or two doses of the vaccinations within a three month period prior to departure, will be allowed to make non-essential travel to 11 Travel Green List nations (Australia, Cambodia, China, Japan, Korea, Malaysia (air travel only), New Zealand, Singapore, United Kingdom, United Arab Emirates, and Saudi Arabia). An exit travel approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office (PMO) is no longer required, particularly for air travel to all countries â whether included in the Travel Green List or otherwise.      -   Cross border travel by land and sea is still suspended.Â       -   Visit the?website of the Prime Ministerâs Office?for outbound travel details.      -   From April 1, 2022, all COVID-19 recovered inbound travelers in the past 90 days are exempted from providing a negative RT-PCR test and mandatory self-isolation with proof of recovery. Antigen Rapid Test (ART) is the only requirement on arrival.      -   All inbound travelers from Green List nations are required to undergo both RT-PCR and ART upon arrival in the country, serve their mandatory self-isolation at respective home residence or hotel until a negative RT-PCR swab test result is obtained, as well as additional Day 2 and Day 3 ART (Day of arrival as Day 1) and upload ART results onto ART Reporting module on BruHealth App.      -   All inbound travelers from Non-Green List nations are required to undergo ART upon arrival, serve their mandatory self-isolation for five (5) days at respective home residence or hotel and undergo RT-PCR test at any accredited clinics on Day 5 post-arrival (Day of arrival as Day 1). Quarantine will be allowed to end as soon as negative RT-PCR swab test result is obtained.      -   Visit the?website of the Prime Ministerâs Office?for inbound travel details.      -   All inbound and outbound travelers for a period of less than 90 days must provide proof of travel health insurance covering COVID-19 (minimum coverage of BND $50,000) from their preferred insurance company before exiting or entering Brunei.      -   Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.  -   Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?Â  **Yes.**      -   Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.  -   Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?Â  **Yes.**      -   Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.  -   Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration. Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/WNIKw

Antigen Rapid Test (ART) is the only requirement on arrival.      -   All inbound travelers from Green List nations are required to undergo both RT-PCR and ART upon arrival in the country, serve their mandatory self-isolation at respective home residence or hotel until a negative RT-PCR swab test result is obtained, as well as additional Day 2 and Day 3 ART (Day of arrival as Day 1) and upload ART results onto ART Reporting module on BruHealth App.      -   All inbound travelers from Non-Green List nations are required to undergo ART upon arrival, serve their mandatory self-isolation for five (5) days at respective home residence or hotel and undergo RT-PCR test at any accredited clinics on Day 5 post-arrival (Day of arrival as Day 1). Quarantine will be allowed to end as soon as negative RT-PCR swab test result is obtained.      -   Visit the?website of the Prime Ministerâs Office?for inbound travel details.      -   All inbound and outbound travelers for a period of less than 90 days must provide proof of travel health insurance covering COVID-19 (minimum coverage of BND $50,000) from their preferred insurance company before exiting or entering Brunei.      -   Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.  -   Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  **Yes.**      -   Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.  -   Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  **Yes.**      -   Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.  -   Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration. Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/Nu4w9

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 08 Apr,    "Face masks are always mandatory in all premises. â¦ Any individual who fails to comply with the directive for wearing face mask will be liable to a compound fine of BND $100 under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204 Section 62A."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/WNIKw  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No changes.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot". No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." 3 April 2022: A total of 666 children received their first dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine on Saturday, as Brunei kicked off its COVID-19 vaccination drive for children ages 5-11.    The Ministry of Health (MoH) said 50,000 first doses have been made available for young children at six vaccination centres across the country.    âThe vaccine is voluntary and it is not being used as a kind of passport for children to be allowed back to school. Itâs part of our effort, besides bertawakkal, to prevent children from developing serious symptoms from COVID-19,â said health minister YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Isham Hj Jaafar.

Universal eligibility for all above age 12.    Brunei will expand its COVID-19 vaccination programme to children aged 5 to 11 commencing this year. The health ministryâs technical team has assessed and approved the use of Pfizer jabs for children below 12.     See the Scoop's article, archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20211206100232/https:/thescoop.co/2021/11/29/brunei-to-vaccinate-5-to-11-year-olds-against-covid-next-year/

The government had previously announced, and maintained that all vaccines would be provided for free to those resident in Brunei, regardless of citizenship.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101213123/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19%20Vaccine.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101235238/https://thescoop.co/2021/04/02/covid-19-brunei-to-begin-mass-vaccination-on-april-3/

On 2022-04-09, the Tianjin Municipal Government issued a circular to strictly control the departure of teachers and students from school. The city implements closed campus management, school teachers and students do not leave Tianjin unless necessary, and do not teach offline unless necessary. For staff, students and outsourced service personnel who do have to leave Tianjin due to family visits and homecoming, etc., they should strictly implement measures to prevent and control the epidemic away from Tianjin, and report to the school before leaving, and provide proof of negative 48-hour nucleic acid tests and health code green codes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143410/https://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/cxzc/202110/t20211020_5657683.html

On 2022-04-06, Shanghai Chongming District issued a notice to suspend offline services at the office lobby of the District Administrative Service Centre during the period of unified implementation of closure and control management (the unsealing time is subject to notification by the prevention and control department) in accordance with the requirements of the epidemic prevention and control work.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410130018/https://www.shcm.gov.cn/ztzl/009004/009004001/20220406/45bfac2a-8ff3-403b-be52-460ba4c1aea5.html

On 2022-04-09, the municipal government of Chengde, Hebei Province, issued a notice that people returning to Chengde should fill in the "Chengde landing code" truthfully, take the initiative to cooperate with the registration of information, check the health code and travel code and other epidemic prevention measures, and take two more nucleic acid tests on the third day and seven days respectively, and refrain from going out until the results are available, and strictly forbid to enter or leave the gathering place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410131016/http://www.hebei.gov.cn/hebei/15067610/15068061/15069930/index.html

On 2022-04-08, the Nanjing Municipal Government issued a circular prohibiting crew members of ships with a history of travel to medium and high risk areas from boarding and disembarking. Those who need to go ashore due to special circumstances such as medical treatment of injuries should be approved by the local health department or the epidemic prevention and control command.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410133455/https://www.jiangsu.gov.cn/art/2022/4/8/art_83410_9986569.html

2022-04-09, Taiyuan City, Shanxi Province, the municipal government issued a circular, foreign entry personnel, the assignment of red code, the first entry point isolation period of 14 days, the return and implementation of "7 days of centralized isolation + 7 days of home isolation" medical observation; the first entry point isolation period of 21 days, the return and implementation of 7 days of home isolation medical observation, the isolation period no abnormal decoding.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220410131745/https://m.thepaper.cn/baijiahao_17432680

No change in policy since 7 Feb 2022.     Businesses, venues, and houses of worship may open at full capacity, adhering to physical distancing. However, high-risk businesses, must operate at 80% capacity. High-risk businesses include cinemas, bars, taverns, gyms, hairdressing and salon services, tattoo parlours, and gaming venues. All establishments must be well ventilated in order to operate.    For Restaurants, CafÃ©s and Food Courts: All eligible persons (employees, customers and clients) must be fully vaccinated. Only in exceptional circumstances where an exemption letter is provided by the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS), an unvaccinated person can enter. Businesses can operate at full capacity of the establishment with adherence to physical distancing and the establishment must be well ventilated. Fiji offers quarantine-free travel to fully vaccinated tourists from Travel Partner countries.   Travellers can now submit either a PCR or RAT negative test result to enter Fiji.  All tests must be supervised and verified by a medical professional (for more info see below) with a written record provided either digitally or on paper.  This should be presented at check in. As of 7th April, Fiji offers quarantine-free travel to fully-vaccinated travellers from all over the world.    To travel to Fiji, simply show evidence of the following at check-in before your departure flight.  - Proof of full vaccination   - A negative pre-departure COVID test (PCR - 48hrs /RAT 24hrs before flight)    - Travel Insurance    - Pre-booked in-country RAT. Since 7 Feb 2022,    Mr Sayed-Khaiyum said the careFIJI App and QR will not be required because we are not presently relying on contact tracing as part of our COVID-19 response.  âThe careFIJI App may be required again in the future if the epidemiological situation changes, so please keep the app on your phone so it is easily available if needed,â Mr Sayed-Khaiyum said    No new information found since. Ministry of Health 1 Apr 22:  We now leave it to you to assess your own level of risk and decide to continue to take measures such as masking and social distancing. If you are at higher risk of severe disease should you get infected with COVID-19, we strongly recommend that you continue to wear a mask in public, particularly in crowded indoor spaces. The lifting of masking and other mandates, and easing of travel restrictions, is NOT a sign that the risk of outbreak and resurgence of COVID-19 is over.    Ministry of Health (1 Apr 22):  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402145943/https://www.health.gov.fj/01-04-2022/    Same information is still reiterated as of 15 Apr 22:  Ministry of Health: https://web.archive.org/web/20220417113758/https://www.health.gov.fj/15-04-2022/

Vaccines available:  Booster dose for individuals aged 18 years and above  First and second doses of the COVID-19 vaccines for individuals aged 18 years and above  First and second doses of the COVID-19 vaccines for individuals aged 15-17 years old  The COVID-19 vaccine is free to the public. The Fijian Government and some key Development Partners like DFAT, MFAT, USAID, WHO and UNICEF are helping absorb all costs associated with the COVID-19 vaccination and its processes.    Ministry of Health & Medical Services Vaccine FAQ:   https://archive.ph/iDdCV  Ministry of Health & Medical Services Vaccine Campaign:   https://archive.ph/z15p0

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology has issued Circular No. 2/2022 on Discretion Towards the Implementation of the four-minister joint decree on schooling during the COVID-19 pandemic. The circular stipulates that those areas where PPKM level 2 are implemented may limit face-to-face schooling to 50% of the class capacity. The decision was taken in consideration of the rise of infections of the Omicron variant of COVID-19 amongst the populace.    https://archive.ph/RXQEq

No policy change    In Java and Bali, areas under level 4 protocols allow non-essential and essential industries to operate on-site at 25 and 50-percent capacity, respectively. Level 3 restrictions permit on-site workforce caps of up to 50 percent in most industries and 75 percent in export-oriented industries. Level 2 curbs allow all sectors to operate on-site at a maximum of 75-percent capacity. Under level 1 protocols, all sectors can run at full capacity.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

In locations at PPKM Level 3 in Java and Bali, most essential and non-essential industries are restricted to a maximum of 50 percent of employees working on-site and 75 percent for export-related businesses. Level 3 locations include the entire Yogyakarta Province; Serang city in Banten Province; and Bangkalan, Lumajang, and Pamekasan regencies in East Java Province.    Outside Java and Bali, Level 3 rules allow nonessential establishments to operate at a maximum of 50 percent capacity on-site, whereas essential businesses may operate at 100 percent. Level 3 locations include the cities of Balikpapan, Banda Aceh, Banjarmasin, Bengkulu, Jayapura, Kupang, Makassar, Padang, Palangkaraya, Palembang, Palu, Pangkalpinang, and Pontianak.    https://archive.ph/ZQtIo

Minister of Home Affairs Tito Karnavian has issued Minister of Home Affairs Instruction (Inmendagri) No. 8/2022 on the prevention and handling of COVID-19 during the Mandalika MotoGP in Pertamina Mandalika International Street Circuit, West Nusa Tenggara 2022. The instruction stipulates a maximum of 100,000 on-site viewers, and a maximum capacity of 10 percent for the festival grounds. All on-site viewers, racers, attendants, crew and officials must also be already fully vaccinated and present a negative PCR test result that is valid for 2x24 hour or a negative Antigen test result that is valid for 1x24 hour    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

With cases of the coronavirus ebbing in Indonesia, the country eased restrictions to allow people to congregate for special prayers that are performed only during Ramadan.    In a statement last week president Joko Widodo announced that the country would ease Covid restrictions for the first time in two years.  The government has also allowed Iftar gatherings in restaurants, malls and cafes. However physical distancing and mask mandates continue to remain in place.    https://archive.ph/ktVJl

All long-distance travelers to and from Java and Bali using all modes of transport are required to show the vaccination card report (first dose is acceptable) and a certificate of negative RT-PCR test or rapid antigen test.    Travelers using air transportation who fly between airports on the island of Java and Bali, including flights from or to Java and Bali are required to present vaccination record (first dose is acceptable) and negative RT-PCR test which was obtained within 48 hours and fill-up e-HAC (Electronic Health Alert Certificate) prior to travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220327182340/https://kemlu.go.id/losangeles/en/news/11727/update-indonesia-travel-restrictions

The COVID-19 Task Force has issued Circular No. 11/2022 and Circular No. 12/2022 that relaxes the health protocol for, respectively, domestic and international travel during the COVID-19 pandemic. Circular No. 11/2022 stipulates that domestic travelers who are completely vaccinated are no longer required to show a negative Antigen or PCR Test Result. Meanwhile, Circular No. 12/2022 stipulates that Indonesians and foreigners travelling from abroad who have been completely vaccinated will only be required to quarantine for 1x24 hours. These circulars take effect starting March 8, 2022.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220326153025/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

Circular No. 11/2022 stipulates that domestic travelers who are completely vaccinated are no longer required to show a negative Antigen or PCR Test Result. Meanwhile, Circular No. 12/2022 stipulates that Indonesians and foreigners travelling from abroad who have been completely vaccinated will only be required to quarantine for 1x24 hours. These circulars take effect starting March 8, 2022.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220326153025/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

The Ministry of Home Affairs has issued Minister of Home Affairs Instruction (Inmendagri) No. 22/2022 on the implementation of PPKM Level 3 to Level 1 on the islands of Java and Bali. The Inmendagri stipulates the extension of the prevailing lockdown policy in Indonesia, known as PPKM, for three weeks or until May 9, 2022. To note, only two areas have been designated to implement PPKM level 3, signifying improved conditions in regards to COVID-19 infection rates in the countryâs most populated islands.    The COVID-19 Task Force has issued Circular No. 16/2022 on domestic travel during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Circular effectively eliminates the requirement of a negative antigen or PCR-Test Result for those who have received their third COVID-19 booster shot to travel domestically. It should be noted that those who have only received up to two shots are still required to show the negative antigen or RT-PCR Test results that is valid for up to 3x24 hour at the time of departure.     Unvaccinated travelers must provide a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours or a RAT test taken within 24 hours before departure. All air and sea travelers must also register on the Health Alert Card (eHAC) mobile application before travel. Officials advise passengers to download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220425192706/https://indonesien.ahk.de/infothek/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia  https://archive.ph/ZQtIo

International travelers may enter Indonesia through the following entry points:  Airports: (i) Soekarno Hatta, Banten; (ii) Juanda, East Java; (iii) Ngurah Rai, Bali; (iv) Hang Nadim, Riau Islands; (v) Raja Haji Fisabilillah, Riau Islands; (vi) Sam Ratulangi, North Sulawesi; (vii) Zainuddin Abdul Madjid, West Nusa Tenggara; (viii) Kualanamu, North Sumatera; (ix) Sultan Hasanuddin, South Sulawesi; and (x) Yogyakarta, Special Region of Yogyakarta.  Seaports: (i) Tanjung Benoa, Bali; (ii) Batam, Riau Islands; (iii) Tanjung Pinang, Riau Islands; (iv) Bintan, Riau Islands; (v) Nunukan, North Kalimantan; (vi) Tanjung Balai Karimun, Riau Islands; and (vii) Dumai, Riau.  Cross-Border Posts: (i) Aruk, West Kalimantan; (ii) Entikong, West Kalimantan; and (iii) Motaâain, East Nusa Tenggara.  Visa on Arrival    Prerequisites for a visa on arrival include:    Passport (diplomatic/official/ordinary) that is valid for a minimum of 6 (six) months,  A return ticket or a pass to continue the trip to another country,  Proof of payment of PNBP Visa on Arrival of 500,000 IDR (in the case of applying for a Visa on Arrival for Leisure Purpose), and  Proof of ownership of health insurance which includes financing for handling COVID-19 and medical evacuation to a referral hospital  Visa on Arrival initial validity is up to a maximum of 30 days and can be extended once for up to another 30 days at the local Immigration Office.    Vaccination    All inbound travelers 12 years and older must be fully vaccinated (complete dose of COVID-19 vaccines, with or without booster) against COVID-19, at least 14 days prior to travel.    Testing    All travelers are required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a sample collected within 48 hours of their departure from point of origin. Upon arrival at the entry points, travelers must undergo a COVID-19 symptom check, including a body temperature check: Â· If the traveler is asymptomatic and has a body temperature below 37.5 degrees Celsius then a RT-PCR test will not be required. Â· If the traveler is symptomatic or has a body temperature above 37.5 degrees Celsius, then a RE-PCR test will be required.    Quarantine    Travelers who have received a full-course of COVID-19 vaccine (single dose of Johnson and Johnson, two doses of all other approved COVID-19 vaccines) at least two weeks prior to travel will not be required to quarantine.  5-day quarantine will be required for travelers who have not been vaccinated or who have not received a full-course of a vaccine.  Travelers under 18 years of age will follow the quarantine provisions of their parents/caregivers.  All foreign travelers who will enter Indonesia must comply with requirements for: vaccination certificates, PCR test provisions, quarantine period, and the use of PeduliLindungi application.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220411231015/https://id.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

International travelers may enter Indonesia through:  Airports: (i) Soekarno Hatta (Jakarta), Banten; (ii) Juanda (Surabaya), East Java; (iii) Ngurah Rai (Denpasar), Bali; (iv) Hang Nadim, Riau Islands; (v) Raja Haji Fisabilillah, Riau Islands; (vi) Sam Ratulangi, North Sulawesi; (vii) Zainuddin Abdul Madjid, West Nusa Tenggara; (viii) Kualanamu, North Sumatera; (ix) Sultan Hasanuddin, South Sulawesi; and (x) Yogyakarta, Special Region of Yogyakarta.  Seaports: (i) Tanjung Benoa, Bali; (ii) Batam, Riau Islands; (iii) Tanjung Pinang, Riau Islands; (iv) Bintan, Riau Islands; (v) Nunukan, North Kalimantan; (vi) Tanjung Balai Karimun, Riau Islands; and (vii) Dumai, Riau.  Cross-Border Posts: (i) Aruk, West Kalimantan; (ii) Entikong, West Kalimantan; and (iii) Motaâain, East Nusa Tenggara.  Visa on Arrival    Travelers applying for visa on arrival must submit::    A passport that is valid for a minimum of 6 (six) months,  A return ticket or onward ticket to another country,  Visa on Arrival fee of 500,000 IDR  Proof of ownership of health insurance which includes financing for COVID-19 and medical evacuation  Visa on Arrival initial validity is up to a maximum of 30 days and can be extended once for up to another 30 days at the local Immigration Office.    Vaccination    All inbound travelers 12 years and older must be fully vaccinated (complete dose of COVID-19 vaccines, with or without booster) against COVID-19, at least 14 days prior to travel. The Indonesian Government recognizes the following vaccinations: two-doses Pfizer, Moderna, Sinovac, AstraZeneca, or Sinopharm and single-dose of Johnson & Johnson    Testing    All travelers are required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a sample collected within 48 hours of their departure from point of origin. Upon arrival, travelers will complete a COVID-19 symptom check, and temperature check. Â· If the traveler is symptomatic or has a body temperature above 99.5 F, a PCR test will be taken at the airport. If this test is positive, the traveler must isolate at their residence or a facility approved for COVID-19 isolation. The traveler is responsible for all associated costs.    Quarantine    There is no quarantine requirement for travelers who are fully- vaccinated  Travelers under 18 years of age will follow the quarantine provisions of their parents/caregivers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220414194525/https://id.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The Ministry of Finance has issued Minister of Finance Regulation No. 3/PMK.03/2022 on Tax Incentive for Taxpayers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Regulation stipulates the extension of the prevailing tax incentive on income tax, import tax on certain importers, as well as final income tax for construction services. The import tax incentive is effective until June 30, 2022, while the income tax and the construction services final income tax incentives is effective until the June 2022 tax period.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

Indonesian President Joko Widodo has signed Presidential Decree No. 24/2021 on the status of COVID-19 in Indonesia. The Decree stipulates that the status of the COVID-19 global pandemic as declared by the World Health Organization remains factual and is also occurring in Indonesia. The decree effectively mandates the ongoing government efforts to support economic stability as well as to prevent further outbreak to continue through 2022.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220425192706/https://indonesien.ahk.de/infothek/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

No change to previous policy. All schools and extracurricular activities continue to be open with precautions in place. Schools may also have the power to temporarily close should there be an outbreak.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412024925/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

The Tokyo Metropolitan Government has extended the "rebound alert period" by about one month to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infection. The rebound alert period involves relaxing the use of restaurants from four people per group to eight people per group from April 24 2022 to May 22 2022. Groups are permitted to remain in restaurants for a maximum of 2 hours.  For uncertified restaurants, there remains a limit of a maximum number of people to 4 per group, stay for 2 hours, in addition to only serving alcoholic beverages before 9pm.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220426024011/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425051456/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220421/k10013593001000.html

Events continue to be permitted and infection precautions are encouraged. There remains a maximum of 5000 people with 100% venue capacity for events with no loud noises, and a maximum of 5000 people with 50% venue capacity for events with loud noises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412024925/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

Events continue to be permitted and infection precautions are encouraged. There remains a maximum of 5000 people with 100% venue capacity for events with no loud noises, and a maximum of 5000 people with 50% venue capacity for events with loud noises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412024925/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

No change to previous policy. Due to the surge of BA.2 variant cases, the government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates. Telework is also encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

No change to previous policy. Due to the surge of BA.2 variant cases, the government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

No change to previous policy. There was a report on April 6 2022 that Japan has lifted travel ban of 106 countries. However, when asked for clarification, the Justice Ministry states, âin reality, there will be no change to who can enter Japan. There wonât be anyone new who will be able to enter Japan as a result of this change.â 106 countries have been lifted from the travel warning registry, where countries rated a '3' are automatically banned from entry.   The Foreign Ministry is still limiting the issuance of visas at embassies overseas, Japan will continue to restrict who can enter the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412025100/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2022/04/06/national/lift-entry-ban-106-countries/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220412025046/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220409184734/https://www.mofa.go.jp/ca/fna/page4e_001053.html

On April 10 2022, Japan will raise their daily upper limit of inbound travellers from 7,000 people to 10,000 people.  However, travel remains restricted to Visa holders and travel for tourism purposes continue not to be permitted entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412024922/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220410/k10013575131000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220412025131/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2022/04/01/national/travel-guidelines-japan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220412025046/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines and support policy documents have been updated as of Apr 1 2022.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.  For note, "Elementary School Leave Subsidy" is a system to support parents who have to take a break from work when the school or nursery school where their children attend is closed or closed due to the influence of COVID. Deadline have been extended until the end of June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412030737/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220409121705/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307060512/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220226/k10013502281000.html

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines and support policy documents have been updated as of Apr 1 2022.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412030737/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220409121705/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

Revised Curfew Order dated 31st March 2022.  Applies from 1st April-29th April 2022    http://archive.today/2022.04.11-172715/https://www.president.gov.ki/resources/gazettes-instruments.html  https://www.president.gov.ki/images/Gazettes/2022/Curfew_Order_English_Version_300322.pdf    Order applies to South Tarawa and Betio, Makin, Butaritari, Marakei, Abaiang, North Tarawa, Maiana, Aranuka and Abemamama.    Curfew 10pm-5am    Government offices and private businesses can open, but must close by 9pm and comply with social distancing and mask wearing indoors and outdoors    restaurants can open for takeaways only    Fishing allowed 5am-10pm, but must not visit other places than point of origin.    Public transport can operate, following SOP guidelines    Schools remain closed until Term 2, except on Kirimati, Tabuaeran, and Teraina.    Kava bars, liquor bars and nightclubs to remain closed.    Social gatherings of up to 20 people in outdoor setting allowed.  Potentially larger gatherings in Church and Parliament allowed following SOP.    Travels to outer islands that are Covid-free are allowed provided rules are followed - negative test before travel and 3 days quarantine on arrival,

These requirements shall take effect from 17 April 2022 0000 hours Myanmar Standard Time.    Ministry of Hotel & Tourism (7 Apr 22):  Travelers shall have a COVID 19 vaccination certificate showing that they were fully vaccinated, at least 14 days before arrival to Myanmar, with one of the following vaccines which has been approved by the Ministry of Health (MOH).    Travelers shall be subject to a thermal screening to be conducted by the respective airport health authorities, upon arrival to Myanmar.  Travelers shall fulfil the following requirements at their own costs;  (a)     a private transportation from the airport to the designated hotel; (b)     a stay at a designated hotel until the result of COVID-19 RT-PCR test; and (A list of designated hotels can be obtained at the website of the Ministry of Hotels and Tourism.) (c)     a COVID-l9 RT-PCR test to be undergone by a laboratory approved by the MOH.  Travelers may check out from the designated hotels, after receiving their test results showing negative for COVID-l9 from the respective health authorities.    Ministry of Hotel & Tourism: https://web.archive.org/web/20220430093245/https://tourism.gov.mm/public-heatth-requirements-for-travelers-who-wish-to-enter-into-myanmar-through-air-transport-7-4-2022/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Burma?  â  YES     Are test results available on the same day?  â  YES     Same-day PCR testing is available at most labs in Yangon.  Please contact the lab in advance to confirm the details of same-day testing.    Testing is available at the following locations:    Yangon Airport Molecular Lab: located on Pyay Road near the Htan Pin Gone bus stop and DHL Myanmar warehouse at the airport.  Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 8:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. with results available the next day.  Same-day testing: swab collection available from 7:00 to 11:30 a.m. with results and certificate available at 6:00 p.m.  The cost of the PCR test is 200,000 MMK. Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "All educational institutions are reopened; institutions under the Ministry of Education will open by stages, subject to risk assessments and the Ministry of Education. Face-to-face learning activities are allowed; face-to-face learning activities by higher education institutions are subject to 70% student capacity limits and SOP". For Phase 4 states, "All educational institutions are reopened, subject to current risk assessment". Vaccination is mandatory for university students to go to campus, but not for other levels.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "All educational institutions are reopened; institutions under the Ministry of Education will open by stages, subject to risk assessments and the Ministry of Education. Face-to-face learning activities are allowed; face-to-face learning activities by higher education institutions are subject to 70% student capacity limits and SOP". For Phase 4 states, "All educational institutions are reopened, subject to current risk assessment". Vaccination is mandatory for university students to go to campus, but not for other levels.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220430102639/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html  https://archive.ph/Y76Mg

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "Public sector limited to 80% employee attendance at offices subject to the Chief Secretary to the Governmentâs directive. Private sector limited to 80% employee attendance capacity, for business sectors allowed to operate. Agricultural and commodities sector may operate at full capacity". Some entertainment business is still closed. "Live performances/events are not allowed".    There is no mention of vaccine mandate policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Some entertainment business is still closed. "Live performances/events are not allowed".    https://web.archive.org/web/20220430102639/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html  https://archive.ph/Y76Mg

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "Live performances/events are not allowed. Only streaming of recordings and live streaming are allowed. Fully Vaccinated Individuals: Allowed to go to live performances/events, cinemas, art exhibitions, museums, indoor buskings and hotel lounges." For fully vaccinated individuals, religious gatherings are allowed subject to capacity limits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. Phase 3 states, "Live performances/events are not allowed. Only streaming of recordings and live streaming is allowed. Fully Vaccinated Individuals: Allowed to go to live performances/events, cinemas, art exhibitions, museums, indoor busking, and hotel lounges." Phase 4 states, Live performances, and events are allowed subject to space capacity and physical distancing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220430102639/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html  https://archive.ph/Y76Mg

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "All social activities and visitations are not allowed". For Phase 4 States, "All social activities and visitations are allowed, limited to 50% space capacity and physical distancing".    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For all states, vehicles may carry passengers at full capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

No recommendations or requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "Travelling between districts of the same state are allowed". For Phase 4 states, "Inter-state travel between phase 4 states is allowed".    Fully Vaccinated Individuals:  Travelling to districts / states / country and tourism bubble areas is allowed    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Fully vaccinated individuals are permitted to enter Langkawi Island as a tourist under the international tourism bubble.     For fully vaccinated individuals, quarantine for 7 days on arrival in Malaysia, reduced to 5 days if one has received a vaccine booster. Citizens and non-citizens who have a residence in Malaysia and arrived from abroad, may have their compulsory quarantine at home.    Non-fully vaccinated individuals must quarantine in a designated quarantine centre for 10 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

PSU is a financial assistance paid to the employer of each enterprise for each local employee.  It is targeted towards employers operating in the tourism sector, who experienced a decrease in income of at least 30% of total sales or income. It is a wage subsidy of RM600 (USD $143) per month for each employee, for 3 months. It is limited to 500 employees per claim.    https://archive.vn/QZHmW

Bank Negara Malaysia (Central Bank of Malaysia) provides loan repayment assistance:  Moratorium for 6 months.  No supporting documentation required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226111954/https://www.bnm.gov.my/RA
The government has a dedicated website for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102417/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

Self-administered Testing kits are now also available to be ordered from the government website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018160735/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/garis-panduan/gp-umum-covid19/kit-ujian-kendiri-covid19-self-test-kit?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

The use of the MySejethera app is not mandated but generally used across Malaysia for many functions including booking vaccinations and tracking social movements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226113805/https://mysejahtera.malaysia.gov.my/intro_en/

Facial coverings are required in Malaysia.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220423140436/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/selangor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Vaccinations are freely available and fully funded by the government for all citizens and foreign residents. Walk-in booster vaccinations for adults 18 years and above opened nationwide on January 29, 2022.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220222083033/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
No specific information on elderly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Tertiary students can attend classes, lectures, labs, workshops, tutorials and meetings in person when tertiary sites are open.  My Vaccine Pass is not required, but tertiary providers may have their own requirements. Check with your provider. If you do not meet their vaccine requirements, talk to them about alternative learning options.  Capacity is based on 1-metre distancing.  Physical distancing is not required    http://web.archive.org/web/20220419052444/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/education-at-red/tertiary-education-at-red/

No major change in policies    vaccine pass no longer necessary    http://web.archive.org/web/20220419050221/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/shopping-and-services-at-red/shops-and-close-proximity-businesses-at-red/

Indoor events are limited to 200 people. There are no capacity limits outdoors.  Face mask at indoor events necessary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404102339/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/

Gatherings can go ahead.  If everyone has a My Vaccine Pass, indoor gatherings are limited to 200 people, and outdoor gatherings have no limit.  Children and babies are included in the gathering limits â but not people working at a gathering.  You do not need to wear a face mask at an outdoor gathering.  At all gatherings, people do not need to physically distance.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220419051527/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/gatherings-and-visits-at-red//

You do not need a My Vaccine Pass to use public transport or taxi and ride-share services. There are no physical distancing requirements on public transport, or at bus stops or train stations. You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220419053300/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/
No requirement for home stay     http://web.archive.org/web/20220419053300/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights. You can travel for any reason.    Some transport providers may require you to show My Vaccine Pass or a negative COVID-19 test result before boarding if you are aged 12 years and 3 months or above.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220419053300/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

Open to current offshore temporary visa holders, who can still meet the relevant visa requirements,  Open to up to 5000 international students for semester 2  Further class exceptions for critical workforces that do not meet the 1.5 times the median wage test will be considered    New Zealand citizens and other eligible travellers entering the country will be able to step off the plane and immediately connect with family and friends and enjoy all New Zealand has to offer.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215081617/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/new-zealand-border-to-reopen-in-stages-from-27-february/  http://web.archive.org/web/20220419055450/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/self-isolation-requirements-removed-step-2-brought-forward/
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20220419060026/https://www.workandincome.govt.nz/covid-19/index.html
No change in policy  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404111816/https://www.workandincome.govt.nz/covid-19/index.html
No change   https://web.archive.org/web/20220404112935/https://covid19.govt.nz/
No change    http://web.archive.org/web/20220419060926/https://covid19.govt.nz/testing-and-tracing/covid-19-testing/how-to-get-a-covid-19-test/
No change in policy   Contract tracing through apps    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404113900/https://covid19.govt.nz/testing-and-tracing/contact-tracing/how-contact-tracing-works/

No facial coverings outside for vaccinated people.  Must wear a face mask in most indoor locations. You do not need to wear a face mask outdoors.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220419061652/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/

There are no stay at home requirements    https://archive.ph/iIIXJ

There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.    Symptomatic people cannot board flights; health staff conduct temperature checks and ban travel for people whose temperatures are 37.5C (99.5F) or higher.    https://archive.ph/cC0ai    https://archive.ph/iIIXJ

As of September 24, 2021, all foreign nationals traveling to Papua New Guinea must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 using an approved vaccine (currently Oxford-AstraZenica; Pfizer-BioNTech; Moderna; Johnson & Johnson; Sinopharm-BBIBP; and CoronaVac Sinovac) unless they are under age 18 or a citizen or permanent resident of Papua New Guinea.    A COVID-19 rapid test is administered upon arrival for all travelers. If negative, the traveler does not have to quarantine. If positive, a PCR test will be performed to confirm the result. If the PCR test is also positive, the traveler must immediately quarantine for 7 days at the travelerâs expense. The traveler is responsible for the cost of the rapid test (capped at PGK200) and possible PCR test.    https://archive.ph/cC0ai    https://archive.ph/AFKmr

On April 2, 2020 the PNG government announced a K5.6 billion economic stimulus package, including a K600 million credit line to support businesses and individuals, in coordination with the banks and financial institutions, and K500 million in support from superannuation savings to employees affected by the economic slowdown.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312165647/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P

All financial institutions agreed to provide relief of 3 months on loan repayments and interest payments to customers who have lost their jobs, on a case-by-case basis. To cover for the 3-month loan repayment holiday for borrowers severely affected by the COVID crisis, BPNG suspended loan-loss provisioning for affected loans during this period    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312165647/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P
There is a co-ordinated public health campaign    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031023630/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/

Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain free or government-subsidized testing services at Port Moresby General Hospital, the Taurama Aquatic Center, and other public clinics in Port Moresby. Testing services outside of Port Moresby may be obtained at provincial hospitals and other health facilities.     Non-symptomatic persons and persons wanting expedited results may obtain services through private medical facilities, including:        2K Medical Clinic      Pacific International Hospital      ASPEN Medical      Sky Health Medical Services      International SOS    Testing conducted through private medical facilities may cost as much as 250 USD.    Though electronic test results from such facilities are generally available within 24-72 hours upon request    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221200426/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Contact tracing is being done    https://web.archive.org/web/20220122215144/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/situation-reports-2/

All persons should where possible wear masks.    No person shall be permitted entry to, or otherwise remain within, any enclosed space without a face mask    No person shall be permitted entry into an aircraft anywhere in PNG unless the person is wearing a Mask or Face Covering    https://archive.ph/8OB74

Eligibility for vaccination includes all persons 18 years of age or older.    AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson, and Sinopharm. Boosters are available for eligible individuals.    https://archive.ph/cC0ai
Booster doses of vaccine have been prioritized for the elderly    https://archive.vn/WhNra

No coding changes for the period of 23 Apr - 05 May 2022.  __________________    Quote (1):  "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.  More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes.    I am still concerned about the COVID-19 situation. Can I choose for my child to remain on Home-Based Learning (HBL) after school reopens?  We would like to reassure parents that schools would be making every effort to implement the various safe management measures to ensure the safety of all students and staff. Allowing your child to return to school would ensure your child's teachers are able to work with your child effectively."    "With the easing of community measures, are there any Vaccination-Differentiated SMMs (VDS) in schools and Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs)? [UPDATED]  [Updated to reflect MTF's Press Release on 22 Apr 2022]    VDS is not implemented in our schools (i.e. COVID-19 vaccination is not a requirement for physical attendance).    However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. These include activities held externally where VDS are applicable. Most of these VDS requirements have since been removed from 26 Apr 2022 onwards, following the updated national VDS posture as announced by the MTF on 22 Apr 2022. For IHLs, in line with national posture, VDS will only apply to events with more than 500 participants and dining in at F&B establishments on IHL campuses."    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20220504035415/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection  --------------------

No coding changes to the period of 05-11 April 2022.    Further easing of COVID safety measures in-country will include resumptions of the nightlife sector from April 19. However, some safety measurements remain in-place, including vaccine-differentiated measurements.  __________________  Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: All nightlife businesses, including nightclubs and discotheques, will be allowed to fully reopen from Apr 19.  This is in line with Singapore's recent easing of COVID-19 measures, said the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) and Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) in a joint media release on Monday (Apr 4). All nightlife establishments will be subjected to the safe management measures imposed on food and beverage outlets, retail liquor establishments and live performances where applicable, said the authorities.    For nightlife businesses where dancing among patrons is one of the intended activities - such as nightclubs and discotheques - patrons have to produce a negative antigen rapid test (ART) before entering the premises. The ART has to be supervised by a test provider approved by the Ministry of Health, either in-person or remotely. The COVID-19 test will be valid for 24 hours from the time of the test result.  "    Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.04.11-033030/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-nightlife-businesses-fully-reopen-april-19-mti-mha-2606391  ________________    Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE: Groups of 10 vaccinated people will be allowed to dine in at food and beverage outlets from Mar 29, in line with Singapore's move to increase the size limit for social gatherings and household visitors. This also applies to hawker centres and coffee shops where full checks on vaccination-differentiated safe management measures (VDS) are implemented at their entrances, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Thursday (Mar 24)."    Link (2): http://archive.today/2022.04.11-033156/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/dining-groups-10-fb-sale-alcohol-live-performances-2582951
